Message.Title: Interesting, the AK-47 was based on a German WW-2 rifle
Message.Msg: Just like a scene out of "Antiques Roadshow," a woman in Hartford, Conn., turned in an old rifle to her local police station's gun buy-back, only to discover the gun was worth anywhere from $20,000 to $25,000. The woman, who wishes to remain anonymous, inherited the gun from her father who had brought it home with him from Europe as a memento from World War II. The two officers conducting the gun buy-back, who are resident gun experts for the Hartford Police Department, informed the owner she was in possession of a Nazi Assault Rifle, the first of its kind, that dates back to 1944. The gun is called a Sturmgewehr 44, literally meaning "storm rifle," and is the first "modern assault rifle ever made, eventually replaced by the AK 47 in 1947 by Russia, who copied the German design of the Sturmgewehr 44," Officer Lewis Crabtree, one of the two officers who discovered the gun, told ABC News.

Topic.Title: Interesting, the AK-47 was based on a German WW-2 rifle

Message.Msg: I had just hired on with PT&T in 1952. Our line gang worked Christmas Day at the Convair plant in San Diego. We went to a second floor engineering floor via an outside staircase. There was a fence covered with black tarps as high as the second floor. We could see over it. It was a German V-2 being redisigned to later become our Atlas missile. I was surprised that we were let into an area where we could see it as the whole program was hush hush. I later did quite a bit of work at Convairs Sycamore Canyon Test Site. Got to go into the bunkers that had all the instrumentation and visual ports with very thick glass. The manholes had 400 lb. lids which we had to use a hoist to pull off.
